data.title: Global Partnership for Education
data.meta_description: The Board of Directors has 20 constituencies representing the different GPE partners.
data.text:
Board member

Hon. Farah Sheikh Abdulkadir is the current Federal Minister of Education, Culture and Higher Education of Somalia. With an overall 30+ years of experience, Hon Abdulkadir has been serving the government leadership for over 10 years. Prior to taking this role, he has served two terms as a federal parliamentarian, Minister of Justice and Constitutional Affairs in 2015 and as State Minister of Somalia Presidency.

Outside of the government sector, he has also served as the Advisor to the Direct Aid, Kuwait and the Country Director of Africa Muslim Agency.

He earned a master’s degree in Business Administration (MBA) from Eastern and Southern Africa Management Institute (ESAMI) Arusha, Tanzania in collaboration with Maastricht School of Management, in Netherlands. He also has a degree in sharia and Law from International Islamic University, in Islamabad Pakistan.

Alternate Board member

In 1996, Moustapha Mohamed Mahamoud, then a young graduate with a master's degree in Geography from the UFR of Human Sciences in Poitiers, returned home, full of dynamism and projects to put himself at the service of his country. He began his career at the Ministry of National Education as a History-Geography teacher until 2004.

At the same time, during the 2003-2004 school year, he provided tutoring to the new university center of Djibouti.

From 2004, he moved up the administrative ladder by being promoted to principal-deputy head of establishment then principal. Roles that he will successively assume in three middle education colleges, while training, for the sake of efficiency, in human resources management (2008-2009) and school mediation (2010-2011).

Thanks to his managerial qualities and his integrity, he became, in 2013, head of department at the general directorate of education. He continues his rise as director of sector monitoring and foresight within the general directorate of technical education and vocational training. And, he was appointed minister in 2016.

Alternate Board member

Wayne Mendiola was born on April 17, 1974 in Pohnpei, FSM. He graduated from Nett Elementary School in Pohnpei, FSM in 1988 with a diploma. He then went on to Xavier High School in Chuuk, FSM and graduated in 1992 with a high school diploma. He then attended College of Micronesia-FSM from 1992 to 1995 an earn an Associate Degree in Liberal Arts and a Third Year Certificate in Teaching.

He started his career 1995 as a school vice principal at Pohnpei Catholic School for 2 years. He then became the principal of Pohnpei Catholic School from 1997 to 2003. While he was the school principal he also took classes at University of Guam and received his Bachelors Degree in Elementary Education in 2000.

In 2003 he started working for the Department of Health Education and Social Affairs office at FSM National Government as the School Health Program Coordinator. In 2007, he then became the Postsecondary Administrator under the Department of Education at the National Government until 2013.

While he was serving as the Postsecondary Administrator, he attended classes online at the San Diego States University (SDSU) and graduated in 2011 with a Masters Degree in Educational Leadership.

From 2013 until today he is the Assistant Secretary of the FSM Department of Education. He is currently the Acting Secretary for the FSM Department of Education. He is currently the Chairman of FSM National Commission for UNESCO; the Chairman of the FSM Nutrition Council, Member of the Pacific Board of Education Quality (PBEQ), member of the Pacific Heads of Education System (PHES).

He is also the a Steering Committee member for the Pacific Island Literacy and Numeracy Assessment (PILNA).

Alternate Board member

Dan Perciun took on the role of Minister in July 2023. From 2019 to 2023, he served as Deputy and Head of the Parliament Commission for Social Protection, Health, and Family. During this time, Mr. Perciun handled a range of tasks, from crafting laws to overseeing programs and conducting evaluations. He actively supported the reform of the social benefits and pensions system in the country.

Since 2014, he's been deeply involved in various activities, such as evaluating the National Strategy in Agriculture 2020 and implementing child-centered education in Moldova. In his stint as Head of the E-transformation Department at the Ministry of Education (2014-2015), he worked on digital competence standards and educational projects in Information Technologies.

As the Minister of Education and Research, Dan Perciun is pushing for reforms to improve education quality and reduce gaps between rural and urban areas. One of his main goals is to establish a network of regional model schools, making education more accessible for vulnerable children.

His priorities also include promoting inclusive education, maintaining integrity, improving teacher's training, and modernizing higher education through digitalization and internationalization. Dan Perciun's dedication to these goals reflects his commitment to making positive changes in education.

Alternate Board member

Annalena Flury-Angelotti is responsible for the Swiss engagement in global education, with expertise in education financing and innovative financing, system governance, inclusion and equity as well as and human rights education. She also represents Switzerland in the International Advisory Committee of the research project Innovative Financing for Education to LNOB.

Ms. Flury-Angelotti has more than 12 years of experience in international development cooperation and humanitarian aid. She has held different positions in Switzerland and abroad managing programs in education, health, human rights and evaluation. She has several years of field experience primarily in West and East Africa including fragile contexts such as Chad, where she was responsible for the education portfolio.

Prior to SDC, Annalena Flury-Angelotti was working at the Office of Gender Equality at the University of Bern and prior to that she served as a Program Manager at the Center for Human Rights Education in Lucerne. She started her career as a journalist and communication expert.

Ms. Flury-Angelotti holds a MA in Political Science, Political Economy and Social Anthropology as well as a Bachelor of Arts in Psychology and Mass Media / Communication Research.

Board member

Sharon Armstrong will begin serving as Director General, Social Development Bureau in Global Affairs Canada in September 2023. Prior to that role, Ms. Armstrong was posted to Canada’s Permanent Delegation to the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in Paris, France, as Deputy Permanent Representative (2018-2023), where she was Canada’s delegate to both the OECD Executive Committee and the External Relations Committee and served as the Vice-Chair to the latter from 2019-2022.

Ms. Armstrong has served the government of Canada since 1996, working to advance Canada’s international interests related to economic and social development, human rights and humanitarian affairs. Initially with the Canadian International Development Agency (CIDA) and now with Global Affairs Canada, Ms. Armstrong has undertaken a series of assignments managing bilateral development assistance programs in the Middle East, Africa, Asia and the Americas.

Prior to representing Canada at the OECD, she served at the Embassy of Canada in Jakarta, Indonesia, from 2015-2018 as Development Director with responsibilities for bilateral program in Indonesia and the regional program with ASEAN. Her previous postings include La Paz, Bolivia (2002-2004) and Geneva, Switzerland (2008-2012).

Ms. Armstrong's work in multilateral contexts also includes being seconded to the WHO to support the Commission on Information and Accountability for Women’s and Children’s Health, which was co-chaired by the Prime Minister of Canada and President of Tanzania. Ms. Armstrong holds a master’s in Business Administration (MBA) from the Université de Genève, Switzerland and a bachelor’s eegree in International Development from the University of Guelph, Canada.

A Haitian national, Nesmy Manigat is a professor of entrepreneurship at the University both in Haiti and abroad. He is also an international consultant and speaker in development, with more than 25 years of experience in the private sector as well as in public and associative institutions, particularly in Africa, Latin America and the Caribbean.

For 10 years, he headed the Department of Small and Medium Enterprises at Quisqueya University in Haiti and subsequently taught entrepreneurship at the Gamal Abdel Nasser University of Guinea and the National School of Arts and Crafts in Conakry.

In 2007, he was at the origin of the agreement on the Cross-Border Observatory of Haitian and Dominican Universities. Member and Vice-President of the Chamber of Commerce, Industry and Professions of the North-East of Haiti in 2012, he promotes technical and vocational training projects in this region in connection with the industrial parks of the area.

An economic journalist and professor-researcher, his numerous studies and publications in both Haitian and foreign newspapers focus on innovation, competitiveness, the relationship between training and employment, local development and official development assistance. Minister of National Education and Vocational Training of Haiti from April 2014 to April 2016, he was reappointed again at the head of the same ministry in November 2021.

In 2016, he was appointed Chairman of the Governance, Ethics, Risk and Financing Committee of the Global Partnership for Education and currently chairs the Finance and Risk Committee. In 2016, he joined the list of "Top Global Thinkers" as Speaker of the Kapuscinski Development Lectures, a famous platform for high-level conferences on development jointly organized by the European Union and UNDP.

As Minister of Education, Nesmy Manigat is known for having taken "12 measures" to improve the governance of the system and the quality of education, published in the official journal Le Moniteur. Among other things, he set up the National Office for Partnership in Education and signed the ministerial decree creating the General Inspectorate of National Education and Vocational Training.

He launched the Early Childhood curriculum, instituted a national assessment from the fourth year of primary school and began the generalization of the "new secondary" of the Bernard reform, which was supposed to be provided according to three main streams: one of general education (in progress), one of technological education and one of pedagogical education.

Supported by the "forum of former ministers of education" that he promoted, he had a national pact for education signed (already proposed by the GTEF) by a large number of representatives of the political class and civil society, aiming, among other things, to double public spending on education.

Mr. Manigat was an International Technical Assistant for 10 years for the European Development Fund (EDF), supporting the management of education systems, both in Haiti and in West Africa, and one of the main advisors to the Working Group on Education and Training (GTEF), Haiti, a presidential commission created in 2007.

Mr. Manigat began his career as a civil servant at the Ministry of Planning and External Cooperation (MPCE) in Haiti before joining the Central Bank of Haiti (BRH). He then held the position of Executive Director of Group Croissance, a research firm that plays an important role as a "think tank" in Haiti in the fields of competitiveness and employment.
